column1: Tijuana (US:  tee-(H)WAH-nə
column2: Spanish: [tiˈxwana] (listen)) is the largest city of both Baja California State and the Baja California Peninsula. It is part of the San Diego–Tijuana transborder urban agglomeration and the larger Southern California megalopolis. As the 6th-largest city in Mexico and center of the 6th-largest metro area in Mexico
column3: Tijuana exerts a strong influence in education and politics – across Mexico
column4: in transportation
column5: culture and art –  across all three Californias (the U.S. state of California
column6: Baja California and Baja California Sur)
column7: and in manufacturing and as a migration hub – across the North American continent. Currently one of the fastest-growing metropolitan areas in Mexico
column8: Tijuana is rated as a "High Sufficiency" global city by the Globalization and World Cities Research Network.As of 2015
column9: the city of Tijuana had a population of 1
column11: 570.Tijuana is located on the Pacific coast of Baja California
column12: and is the municipal seat and the cultural and commercial center of Tijuana Municipality (Mexican states are divided into municipalities
column13: rather than counties as in the U.S.). Tijuana covers 70% of the territory of the municipality and contains 80% of its population. A dominant manufacturing center of the North American continent
column14: the city maintains facilities of many multinational conglomerate companies. In the early 21st century
column15: Tijuana became the medical-device manufacturing capital of North America. Tijuana is also a growing cultural center and has been recognized as an important new cultural mecca. The city is the most visited border city in the world; sharing a border of about 24 km (15 mi) with its sister city San Diego. More than fifty million people cross the border between these two cities every year. This metropolitan crossing makes the San Ysidro Port of Entry the fourth busiest land-border crossing in the world. It is estimated that the two border crossing stations between the cities proper of San Diego and Tijuana account for 300
column16: 000 daily border crossings alone.Tijuana is the 45th largest city in the Americas and is the westernmost city in Mexico.  According to the 2015 census
column17: the Tijuana metropolitan area was the fifth-largest in Mexico
column22: the city (locality) itself was 6th largest and the municipality (administrative) 3rd largest nationally.  The international metropolitan region was estimated at about 5
column25: making it the third-largest metropolitan area in the former Californias region
column26: 19th largest metropolitan area in the Americas
column27: and the largest bi-national conurbation that is shared between US and Mexico.  Tijuana is becoming more suburbanized like San Diego.

column1: Tijuana traces its modern history to the arrival of Spanish explorers in the 16th century who were mapping the coast of the Californias. As the American occupation of the Mexican capital ended with the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo
column2: Tijuana's new international position on the border gave rise to a new economic and political structure. The city was founded on July 11
column3: 1889 as urban development began. Often known by its supposed initials
column4: T.J.
column5: and nicknamed Gateway to Mexico
column6: the city has historically served as a tourist center dating back to the 1880s.

column1: == Name ==
=== Etymology ===
The city's name comes from the rancho that Santiago Argüello Moraga established in 1829 on his Mexican land grant
column2: naming it Rancho Tía Juana.The first Spanish mission call the settlement variously as La Tía Juana
column3: Tiguana
column4: Tiuana
column5: Tiwana
column6: Tijuan
column7: Ticuan
column8: as well as Tijuana. While the Mexican city standardized to Tijuana
column9: the American term for both the river and a U.S. settlement which is now part of San Ysidro remained Tía Juana until the mid-20th century.

column1: The commonly accepted theory among historians is that Tía Juana
column2: as Argüello named his rancho
column3: is derived from the word Tiwan ("by the sea") in the language of the Kumeyaay—the original aboriginal inhabitants of the San Diego-Tijuana region. Urban legend
column4: however
column5: states that Tía Juana
column6: which means "Aunt Jane" in Spanish
column7: was a real person whose inn provided food and lodging to travelers. There is however no record of such an inn; in fact the first building in the area was built by Argüello in any case
column8: after naming his ranch Rancho Tía Juana.

column1: === Nicknames ===
In Southern California
column2: Tijuana is often referred to as TJ or T.J. Baja Californians have adopted this pronunciation as Tiyei. In Spanish the demonym for someone from Tijuana is Tijuanense
column3: while in English the demonym is Tijuanan. A very common slang term used for a person from Tijuana is Tijuanero.The nickname Tijuas is increasingly popular among residents and visitors alike. Due to a recent increase in violence in the city
column4: a new term is developing. The phrase Yo Tijuaneo
column5: ¿y tú? translates to I Tijuanate
column6: and you?. This term comes from a new popular local verb Tijuanear meaning to Tijuana
column7: describing the cosmopolitan aspects of living in the city and frequently crossing the border.

column1: == History ==
=== Origins ===
The land was originally inhabited by the Kumeyaay
column2: a tribe of Yuman-speaking hunter-gatherers. Europeans arrived in 1542
column3: when the explorer Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo toured the coastline of the area
column4: which Sebastián Vizcaíno mapped in 1602. In 1769
column5: Juan Crespí documented more details about the area that was later called the Valley of Tijuana. Junípero Serra founded the first mission of Alta California in nearby San Diego.

column1: Further settlement took place near the end of the mission era when José María de Echeandía
column2: governor of the Baja California and Alta California
column3: awarded a large land grant to Santiago Argüello in 1829. This large cattle ranch
column4: Rancho Tía Juana
column5: covered 100 km2 (40 sq mi). Although "Tia Juana" means "Aunt Jane" in Spanish
column6: the name was actually an adaptation of the word 'Tihuan' or 'Tijuán' in the Kumeyaay language
column7: the name of a nearby Kumeyaay settlement and whose meaning is disputed.In 1848
column8: as a result of the Mexican–American War with the United States
column9: Mexico lost all of Alta California. The majority of the 1
column10: 000 Hispanic families living in Alta California stayed there
column11: though some moved south to remain inside Mexico. Because of this Tijuana gained a different purpose on the international border. The area had been populated by ranchers
column12: but Tijuana developed a new social economic structure. These were farming and livestock grazing
column13: plus as a transit area for prospectors.

column1: === 1889–1915: Town established ===
Urban settlement began in 1889
column2: when descendants of Santiago Argüello and Augustín Olvera entered an agreement to begin developing the city of Tijuana. The date of the agreement
column3: July 11
column5: is recognized as the founding of the city. Tijuana saw its future in tourism from the beginning. From the late 19th century to the first few decades of the 20th century
column6: the city attracted large numbers of Californians coming for trade and entertainment. The California land boom of the 1880s led to the first big wave of tourists
column7: who were called "excursionists" and came looking for echoes of the famous novel "Ramona" by Helen Hunt Jackson.

column2: during the Mexican Revolution
column3: revolutionaries claiming loyalty to Ricardo Flores Magón took over the city for shortly over a month. Federal troops then arrived. Assisted by the "defensores de Tijuana"
column4: they routed the revolutionaries
column5: who fled north and were promptly arrested by the United States Army.

column1: The Panama-California Exposition of 1915 brought many visitors to the nearby California city of San Diego. Tijuana attracted these tourists with a Feria Típica Mexicana – Typical Mexican Fair. This included curio shops
column2: regional food
column3: thermal baths
column4: horse racing and boxing.

column1: === 1916–1935: Gambling and drinking destination ===
The first professional race track opened in January 1916
column2: just south of the border gate. It was almost immediately destroyed by the great "Hatfield rainmaker" flood of 1916. Rebuilt in the general area
column3: it ran horse races until the new Agua Caliente track opened in 1929
column4: several miles south and across the river on higher ground.

column1: Legal drinking and gambling attracted U.S nationals in the 1920s during Prohibition. The Avenida Revolución area became the city's tourist center
column2: with casinos and the Hotel Caesar's
column3: birthplace of the Caesar salad.

column2: the city by presidential decree changed his name to   ciudad Zaragoza
column3: but its name reverted to Tijuana in 1929.

column2: the Agua Caliente Touristic Complex was opened
column3: including hotel
column4: spa
column5: dog-track
column6: private airport
column7: golf course and gambling casino. A year later
column8: the new Agua Caliente Racetrack joined the complex. During the eight years it operated
column10: casino and spa achieved a near mythical status
column11: with Hollywood stars and gangsters flying in and playing. Rita Hayworth was discovered there. Musical nightclub productions were broadcast over the radio. A singer known as "la Faraona" got shot in a love-triangle and gave birth to the myth of a beautiful lady ghost. Remnants of the Agua Caliente casino can be seen in the outdoor swimming pool and the "minarete" (actually a former incinerator chimney) nearby the southern end of Avenida Sanchez Taboada
column12: on the grounds of what is now the Lazaro Cardenas educational complex.

column1: === 1935–1965: Tourism broadens ===

column2: President Cárdenas decreed an end to gambling and casinos in Baja California
column3: and the Agua Caliente complex faltered
column4: then closed. In 1939
column5: it was reopened as a junior high school (now
column6: Preparatoria Lázaro Cárdenas). The buildings themselves were torn down in the 1970s and replaced by modern scholastic architecture.

column1: With increased tourism and a large number of Mexican citizens relocating to Tijuana
column2: the city's population grew from 21
column4: 364 between 1940 and 1950.

column1: With the decline of nightlife and tourism in the 1950s
column2: the city restructured its tourist industry
column3: by promoting a more family-oriented scene. Tijuana developed a greater variety of attractions and activities to offer its visitors.

column1: === 1965–2001: The city matures ===

In 1965 the Mexican federal government launched the Border Industrialization Program to attract foreign investment. Tijuana and other border cities became attractive for foreign companies to open maquiladoras (factories)
column2: and the Tijuana economy started to diversify. Manufacturing jobs attracted workers from other parts of Mexico and the city's population grew from less than half a million in 1980 to almost 1 million in 1985.
work began on the first concrete channeling of the Tijuana River; previously the river would flood across a wide plain east and southeast of downtown
column3: inundating an area of wood
column4: cardboard and metal shacks called Cartolandia (“Paperland”).  The project removed the shacks and added 1.8 million sq. m. of usable land
column5: on which the Zona Río was built. With the 1981 opening of the Plaza Río Tijuana mall and the 1982 Tijuana Cultural Center (CECUT)
column6: Zona Río became the new commercial center of a modern Tijuana
column7: and with its new boulevards with monument-filled glorietas (roundabouts)
column8: reminiscent of the grand Paseo de la Reforma in Mexico City
column9: the city created the new image and allure of a modern
column10: large city
column11: rather than just a border town focused on tourism and vice.In 1994
column12: PRI presidential candidate Luis Donaldo Colosio was assassinated in Tijuana while making an appearance in the plaza of Lomas Taurinas
column13: a neighborhood nestled in a valley near Centro. The shooter was caught and imprisoned
column14: but doubts remain about who the mastermind might have been.

column1: === 2001–2011: Violence and decline of US tourism ===
After 9/11
column2: tighter US border controls resulted in hours-long waits to return to the US. The number of US visitors dropped sharply due to this factor
column3: as well as subsequent drug violence.Around 2008
column4: thousands of Tijuana's elite bought houses in and moved to Bonita and Eastlake in Chula Vista
column5: California to escape violence
column6: kidnapping and other crimes taking place during that period. An article in The Los Angeles Times reported that the emigration to San Diego County has transformed the demographic and cultural character of some cities to a degree.

column1: === 2011–present: Tijuana strengthens ===
In recent years
column2: Tijuana has become an important city of commerce and migration for Mexico and US. In spite of the violence and border crossing issues
column3: the city has received a large number of tourists from US
column4: China
column5: Japan and the south of Mexico. Thanks to the realization of cultural and business festivals
column6: the city has improved its image before the world
column7: standing out as a competitive city for investment. Currently
column8: the commercial and business sector is committed to the boom in the gastronomic industry
column10: entertainment and real estate
column11: as well as medical tourism

column1: == Geography ==
Tijuana is the westernmost city in Mexico
column2: and consequently in Latin America
column3: and the second largest city of northern Mexico. Located about 210 kilometers (130 mi) west of the state capital
column4: Mexicali
column5: the city is bordered to the north by the cities of Imperial Beach
column6: and the San Diego neighborhoods of San Ysidro and Otay Mesa
column7: California. To the southwest of the city is Rosarito Beach
column8: while to the south is unincorporated territory of Tijuana Municipality. The city is nestled among hills
column10: and gullies. The central part of the city lies in a valley through which flows the channeled Tijuana River.

column1: Housing development in the Tijuana Hills has led to eradication of many seasonal mountain streams. This lack of natural drainage makes places within the city vulnerable to landslides during the rainy season. The varied terrain of Tijuana gives the city elevation extremes that range from sea level to 790 meters (2
Tijuana is noted for its rough terrain
column2: which includes many canyons
column3: steep hills
column4: and mesas. Among noted canyons in Tijuana are Canyon K and Canyon Johnson. Large Tijuana hills include Red Hill (Cerro Colorado) and Hill of the Bees (Cerro de las Abejas) in the eastern part of the city.

column1: The city is located near the terminus of the Tijuana River and within the Tijuana River Basin. The Tijuana River is an intermittent river
column2: 195 km (121 mi) long
column3: on the Pacific coast of northern Baja California in Mexico and Southern California in the United States. It drains an arid area along the California–Baja California border
column4: flowing through Mexico for most of its course and then crossing the border for the last 8 km (5 mi) of its course where it forms an estuary that empties into the ocean. The river's lower reaches harbor the last undeveloped coastal wetlands in San Diego County
column5: and some of the last in Southern California
column6: amidst a highly urbanized environment at the southern city limits of Imperial Beach.

column1: As downtown Tijuana was built at the bottom of the river valley
column2: the district is subject to seasonal flooding created by drain-off from the Tijuana Hills. During this time
column3: east-bound portions of the Via Rapida (east-west highway) may be blocked off by the Tijuana Police due to hazardous conditions.

column1: === Cityscape ===

The city's skyscraper history is relatively recent. Some of the first highrise building complexes constructed in the city were the twin towers of Grand Hotel Tijuana. Tijuana experienced a building boom that was brought to a halt by the Great Recession. Among buildings that succumbed to the time period was the Trump Ocean Resort Baja Mexico that would have been located in Playas and reached 98 m (322 ft). Currently the tallest building
column2: and soon to be the largest complex in footage
column3: New City Residential reaches 102 m (335 ft). Overall
column4: the city maintains 33 completed structures with other proposed and under-construction skyscrapers.

column1: The Tijuana skyline is the fifth largest skyline in Mexico and is located in the Zona Rio and to a smaller extent
column2: Playas de Tijuana. In the Zona Rio the buildings are concentrated on the Tijuana River
column3: lined parallel to the river; and on the edges of the Tijuana Country Club. In Playas the high rises are currently focused on the coast. Recent construction on high rises has begun in the aforementioned areas
column4: as buildings such as New City Residential and Grand Hotel Tijuana have been developed and taken prominent places in the skyline as the tallest buildings. From Tijuana's skyline the San Diego skyline can also be seen
column5: although the reverse is mostly not true on account of the high hills surrounding central Tijuana.

column1: === Boroughs and neighborhoods ===
The municipality of Tijuana is divided into eight administrative boroughs
column2: or Delegaciones. The Tijuana metropolitan area occupies all of borough seats. The boroughs are in turn divided into colonias or ejidos. These boroughs offer administrative services such as urban planning
column3: civil registry
column4: inspection
column5: verification
column6: public works and community development and are served by a delegado.

column1: Centro — "Delegación Centro" includes the old downtown (Zona Centro)
column2: new business district (Zona Río)
column3: red light district (Zona Norte)
column4: and other adjacent neighborhoods ("zonas"). This is the historical midpoint of Tijuana; the municipal palace is located here as well as most of the tourist zones
column5: such as Avenida Revolución and the business district. The Tijuana Cultural Center (CECUT for CEntro CUltural de Tijuana) is located here as well as the Plaza Río Tijuana
column6: until recently the largest mall in the state
column7: within the Zona Rio.

column1: Cerro Colorado — The Cerro Colorado ("Red Hill") is located here and it is surrounded by houses. Because of its height many of the area's antennae for radio and television stations are located on its peak.
La Mesa — This is where the Morelos Park
column2: the largest public park in the city
column3: is located
column4: as well as the retail and transit hub Cinco y Diez
column5: Plaza Mundo Divertido
column6: the new Macroplaza and the CETYS University.

column1: Otay Centenario — This borough was created in 2014 by merging Mesa de Otay and Centenario boroughs. In this borough sits the Tijuana International Airport.  The Tijuana campus of the Autonomous University of Baja California and the Technologico are also located here as well as many maquiladoras. This is the borough with the largest number of factories and maquiladoras. Its largest colony is Ciudad Industrial ("Industrial City"). Three of the city's most important streets
column2: Boulevard Bellas Artes
column3: Boulevard Industrial and Fed 2
column4: are located here.  This delegacion contains the Otay Mesa entry to the United States and the Friendship Park (Parque de la amistad).

column1: Playas de Tijuana — This is the westernmost borough of the city bordered by the Pacific Ocean on the west and the United States border on the north. This is where the beaches of Tijuana are located (hence the name) and it is also one of the two exits to the south towards Rosarito and Ensenada.
La Presa — literally "'the dam'"
column2: this is the largest borough in size and the Abelardo L. Rodríguez Dam is located within its limits
column3: hence its name. The new Corredor Tijuana-Rosarito 2000 and the Tijuana-Tecate freeways run through it.

column1: San Antonio de los Buenos — This is mostly a residential area although it also has two industrial parks.
Sanchez Taboada — Like the previous borough this is mostly a residential area
column2: but within its borders are located many "maquiladoras" specially at Pacific Industrial Park.

column1: === Climate ===
Tijuana's climate is a semi-arid (Köppen climate classification BSh)
column2: with about 231 mm (9.09 in) of annual precipitation
column3: and generally mild to warm weather year-round. It has characteristics of the Mediterranean climate (Csa) found to the immediate north
column4: with most of the annual precipitation falling in the winter
column5: between the months of November and March.

column1: Between November and March
column2: storms originate from fronts entering off of the Pacific Ocean. January is the wettest month of the year for the city and during this time a periodic event
column3: similar to June Gloom
column4: is observed created by marine layer. January is the coolest month
column5: during which temperatures average 13.6 °C (56.5 °F). In the city April signifies the end of winter and the start of Santa Ana winds. Though the daytime highs are generally around 20 °C (68 °F)
column6: heat waves can reach up to 33 °C (91 °F). The hottest months in the city are August and September
column7: during which temperatures average 22.0 °C (71.6 °F). Summers are by far the driest time of year since influences from the California Current and the North Pacific High suppress the formation of rainfall caused by the North American Monsoon. As in coastal Southern California
column8: air pollution sometimes occurs during periods of temperature inversion
column10: but (unlike Mexico City) is seldom severe and in recent years has lessened due to cleaner car engines.Frost and snow are rare phenomena in the city as temperatures are usually well above freezing. Yet
column11: in December 1967
column12: snow fell in the city and in January 2007 feather light snow fell in the east of the city. However
column13: excessive amounts of snow fall have never been recorded in the city. On February 14
column14: 2008 a winter storm caused an unusual snowfall in the upper reaches of the hills of the city.

column1: The record low temperature recorded in the city was −6 °C (21 °F)
column2: while the highest was 49 °C (120 °F).

column1: == Demographics ==
Tijuana has a diverse cosmopolitan population which includes migrants from other parts of Mexico and from all over the world. Tijuana has one of Mexico's largest Asian populations
column2: predominantly consisting of Chinese
column3: Koreans
column4: and Japanese immigrants. Tijuana also has a large and rapidly growing population of United States citizens
column5: mostly from Southern California.  Many Latin Americans
column6: notably Cubans
column7: and Guatemalans
column8: have made Tijuana their home. The city also has many Lebanese
column10: French
column11: Spanish citizens. Recently
column12: the city has received a large influx of Haitian immigrants.

column1: The majority of Tijuana's migrant Mexican population hail from Sinaloa
column2: Michoacán
column3: Jalisco
column4: Oaxaca
column5: and the Federal District. Because of the diversity of Mexico and the influx of immigrants from almost every region in the country
column6: there are no accurate estimates on ethnicity or race of the current population. The heavy influx of immigrants to the city and municipality of Tijuana has led to job creation in the form of over 700 twin-plant (maquiladora) factories
column7: which serve as the basis of employment for the majority of the working-class people in northern Mexico.  The high poverty level in Tijuana is attributed to the city's "magnet status" for people who have come from the poorer south of the nation and citizens from other nations seeking to escape from extreme poverty.  Tijuana holds a status that provides the possibility of employment as well as higher education and the dream of crossing the border.  Tijuana and Baja California in general have much stronger economies and higher incomes than other Mexican cities along the United States border
column8: as well as more moderate weather.

column1: Tijuana today is one of the fastest growing cities in Mexico with an average of 80
column2: 000 people moving to Tijuana yearly.  In terms of area
column3: the city grows by approximately three hectares a day
column4: mostly east and south as the city is mostly built out to the beach already with the exception of some canyons.  Along with settlements separated from Tijuana proper and other communities unimproved land
column5: big business moves in providing supermarkets and retail to marginal areas
column6: along with paved roads.  The city experiences the construction of 26
column7: 000 new settlers a year that has led to the unregulated
column8: illegal squatter homes that takes place in the hills and valleys of ever expanding Tijuana
column9: most of these areas are still without city services like sidewalks
column10: paving
column11: streetlights
column12: and public transit. This is an ongoing process: as older and existing squatter areas are brought into the city services
column13: more marginal areas become occupied by squatters.

column1: Squatter areas are home to displaced and uprooted people
column2: among them the indigenous and poverty stricken

column4: many of whom are also without Mexican citizenship.  In recent years
column5: working-class suburban housing estates have sprung up in the fringes to provide a sense of safety and land ownership.  These suburbs enable young families to isolate their families from the violence of the drug war and squatter areas.  These outlying communities tend to be much better equipped than their squatter counterparts.  Nevertheless
column6: some remote areas are drug plantations for narcotics
column7: and delinquency has spread to areas once considered safe havens.  These issues occasionally come to light in the newspapers.

column1: === Crime ===
Tijuana is the birthplace and base of the Tijuana Cartel.  From 2007 through 2010
column2: Tijuana experienced an unusually high level of violent crime related to gang violence
column3: in part derived from the Mexican drug war and human trafficking.  Homicides peaked in 2010
column4: when 844 people were killed
column5: compared with 355 in 2004 and 349 in the first eight months of 2011. Reportedly
column6: the wave of violence resulted from a turf war as the administration of President Felipe Calderón weakened the local Arellano Félix cartel; violence slowed when the larger Sinaloa cartel took control.During peak years of violent crime in the city
column7: gun battles between rival cartels
column8: and between cartels and the police
column10: police found 1
column11: 500 shell casings on various streets after one battle left 13 suspected drug traffickers dead. In 2009 and depending on the source
column14: mostly as a result of the drug war.There were 492 murders in 2013
column15: a 48% increase in the homicide rate between 2012 and 2013. This was the highest number of murders since 2010. By the end of 2017
column16: the number of murders in Tijuana increased to 1
column18: which was almost double those in 2016.As of 2018
column19: Tijuana had the highest per capita rate for homicides in the world at 138 murders per 100

column1: == Government ==
=== Region ===
At present the parties with greater presence in Tijuana are the National Action Party (PAN)
column2: Institutional Revolutionary Party (PRI)
column3: and Ecologist Green Party of Mexico (PVEM). The PAN has been the dominant party in the city for 20 years. Historically the PRI had been the dominant party in regional politics
column4: until 1989 when the PAN began to dominate the city
column5: until yet again
column7: PRI began regaining prominence and won the Mayor's Office.

column1: Less prominent parties also maintain relations with the dominant parties. These other parties
column2: with less presence include the New Alliance Party (PANAL)
column3: Social Encounter Party (PES)
column4: and Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD). Allied with the PAN at the state and local level under the Alliance for Baja California are the Social Encounter Party (PES) and New Alliance Party (PANAL). Allied with the PRI at the state and local level under the "Alliance for Better Living" are the Ecologist Green Party of Mexico (PVEM) and Baja California State Party (PEBC).

column1: === International ===
Tijuana's importance and rise to a global city has led to its recognition among countries worldwide. In addition to international cultural recognition
column2: Tijuana has received political recognition and is a developing a political center currently host to eight consulates from European
column3: Asian
column4: and North American countries.

column1: == Economy ==
=== Manufacturing ===
Tijuana is a large manufacturing center
column2: and in addition to tourism
column3: it serves as a cornerstone of the city economy. In the past decade alone
column4: Tijuana became the medical device manufacture capital of the North American continent
column5: surpassing previous leader Minneapolis - Saint Paul.The city's proximity to Southern California and its large
column6: skilled
column7: diverse
column8: and relatively inexpensive workforce make it an attractive city for foreign companies looking to establish extensive industrial parks composed of assembly plants that are called maquiladoras
column9: even more so than other cities in the US-Mexican border zone
column10: taking advantage of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) to export products. At its peak
column11: in 2001 Tijuana had roughly 820 of these 'maquiladoras'. Foreign and domestic companies employ thousands of employees in these plants
column12: usually in assembly-related labor. Such jobs are not demanding but typically offer above average salaries for Mexico
column13: with most maqiladoras jobs beginning at Mex$100 per day (about 5 US dollars
column15: significantly above the Mexican minimum wage of Mex$57.46 (about 3 US dollars
column16: as of September 2016). Companies that have set up maquiladoras in Tijuana include Lanix
column41: Sanyo and Volkswagen. Many of the maquiladoras are located in the Otay Mesa and Florido sections of Tijuana.

column1: Economic development has its central business district at Zona Río
column2: which together
column3: with the corridor along Blvd. Agua Caliente (the extension of Avenida Revolución)
column4: contains the majority of the higher-end office space in the city.

column1: === Tourist economy and entertainment ===
Tijuana also relies on tourism for a major part of its revenue. About 300
column2: 000 visitors cross by foot or car from the San Ysidro point of entry in the United States every day. Restaurants and taco stands
column3: pharmacies
column4: bars and dance clubs
column5: and shops and stalls selling Mexican crafts and souvenirs are part of the draw for the city's tourists
column6: many located within walking distance of the border. The city's tourist centers include Downtown Tijuana including the nightlife hot spots around La Sexta
column7: Avenida Revolucion
column8: souvenir shopping at the Mercado de Artesanías and Plaza Viva Tijuana
column9: Tijuana's Cultural Center (CECUT) and neighboring Plaza Río Tijuana shopping center
column10: and the city's best known vices
column11: in the form of its legal Red Light District and gambling (Agua Caliente). Mexico's drinking age of 18 (vs. 21 in the United States) makes it a common weekend destination for many high school and college aged Southern Californians who tend to stay on Avenida Revolución.

column1: Tijuana is also known for its red-light district Zona Norte (also referred to as La Coahuila after one of its main streets) with legal prostitution in strip clubs and on the street. The strip clubs are typically full-contact
column2: meaning the dancers let patrons fondle them. Many dancers also sell their sexual services. In a 1999 estimation
column3: there were 15
column4: 000 women engaged in prostitution in Tijuana outside of clubs and brothels.Tijuana has many pharmacies that target visitors from the United States
column5: which sell some medicines without prescriptions and/or at much lower costs than in the U.S. Many medications still require a Mexican prescription
column6: which can be obtained from adjacent doctors' offices. People filling up prescriptions for drugs classified in the US as Schedule II or Schedule III have found it more difficult to locate such medications
column7: and the purchase of pseudoephedrine also has become restricted by Tijuana pharmacies
column8: just as in the U.S. To fill a prescription in Tijuana for any drug covered by the US Controlled Substances Act  and legally bring it into the United States requires a prescription from the United States for re-import.  Americans can import up to a 90-day supply of non-controlled medications for personal use to the USA from Mexico and other countries.

column1: Businesses such as auto detailing
column2: medical and dental services and plastic surgery are heavily marketed
column3: and are usually much less expensive than in the U.S.

column1: Tijuana is headquarters for Mexico's largest gambling concern
column2: Grupo Caliente
column3: which operates the only casinos in the city
column4: more than twenty branches.Tourists are sometimes robbed by municipal police.

As Tijuana matured from a tourist-oriented border town into one of Mexico's largest cities

column7: a restaurant
column8: café

column1: === Parks and recreation ===
Parque Morelos has a small zoo and park space; Parque de la Amistad in Otay Centenario has a small pond
column2: and a running and dirt-bike track. Parque Teniente Guerrero is a downtown park with a public library and weekend entertainment by clowns.

column1: === Nightlife ===
Tijuana's nightlife scene is one of the city's strongest attractions. The area surrounding "La Sexta"
column2: the intersection at Calle Sexta and Av. Revolución
column3: is now a major hub of new bars and dance clubs. Zona Rio
column4: Tijuana's new Downtown
column5: is home to some of the city's finest restaurants and bars. Another capstone of Tijuana's entertainment offerings is its adult nightlife industry
column6: which includes the city's red light district as well as less conspicuous adult entertainment venues.

column1: Tijuana also has a very active and independent artist community whose internationally recognized work has earned Tijuana the title of "one of the most important new cultural meccas"
column2: according to Newsweek
column3: an exhibition of Tijuana's current art scene
column4: is being curated by the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego and is traveling across the USA in 2006 and 2007. Art collectives like Bulbo and film production like Palenque Filmaciones explore the use of film like the award-winning Tijuana Makes Me Happy
column5: media like television bulbo TV and print "bulbo PRESS"
column6: to show different realities of Tijuana out of Mexico. In 2004
column7: Tijuana earned international acclaim for an art exhibition displayed on the cement banks of the Tijuana River and along the Mexico/U.S. border fence in Otay Mesa.

column1: Graffiti is widespread in Tijuana. They can range from free-hand writing in spray can and marker form
column2: often carrying social or sexual commentary in English or Spanish
column3: pictures in wheatpaste and stencils
column4: consisting of stenciled renderings of personalities crucial to Hispanic culture from past and present eras
column5: such as television news announcers or stars
column6: but also extending to images of artists like Salvador Dalí. Graffiti in Tijuana may seem at first to consist largely of simplistic tags and thus not as technically evolved
column7: colorful
column8: or accepted in the mainstream as the "pieces" of graffiti scenes of the United States
column10: or Japan
column11: but large
column12: colorful graffiti murals adorn walls from both native Tijuanan artists as well as visiting graffiti writers
column13: especially from California. The Tijuanan art pieces show as much prowess and skill as those made by their more renowned U.S. counterparts
column14: although illicit graffiti are strongly discouraged by the Tijuana government
column15: as in other major metropolitan areas.

column1: == Sports ==

The city is home to the Tijuana Zonkeys professional basketball team of the CIBACOPA basketball league. The team is composed mostly of players from Mexico and plays from February to July in the Municipal Auditorium.
The city has a strong tradition of association football
column2: Club Tijuana began playing in the Liga MX México Primera División on the 2011/12 season

column4: a new 33
column5: 000 seat stadium. The team's mascot is the Xoloitzcuintle
column6: a famous Mexican hairless dog.

column1: Tijuana also has a long history of producing many world champion professional boxers
column2: such as Antonio Margarito and Erik Morales.

column1: == Infrastructure ==
=== Utilities ===
The Tijuana State Commission of Public Services (CESPT) supplies the city with its water
column2: while the city receives its electricity from La Comisión Federal de Electricidad (CFE).
due to extremely low water levels at El Carrizo Reservoir
column3: CESPT began a city-wide water rationing scheme. This rationing scheme would divide Tijuana and nearby Rosarito into 5 zones. Each zone would be cut-off from the water supply on a rotating schedule of 4 days with water and 1 day without water. This scheme was expected to last for at least 2 months until the water levels at El Carrizo Reservoir were improved.

column1: ==== Wastewater ====
The International Boundary Wastewater Treatment Plant (IWTP) developed
column2: as a joint project of the USA and Mexico in the mid-1980s following substantial environmental studies
column3: treats 25 million gallons of water per day (mgd) from the Tijuana River; directly pumped across the border from the central collection point in Mexico. When the river is flowing
column4: the diversion system of the plant begins operating and diverts up to about 12-13mgd to the IWTP. The total amount of water being diverted must not exceed 25 mgd
column5: based on a monthly average decided upon by permit conditions
column6: although the IWTP can treat sustained flows up to 45mgd daily and peaks of 70mgd for a short period. The diversion system regularly sends approximately six to eight million gallons of water daily to the IWTP. The plant is currently being upgraded to include a secondary treatment facility.

column1: The city also four to five decentralize units that are part of the Tijuana/Rosarito Potable Water and Wastewater Master Plan. This plan was required as part of Public Law 106-457
column2: put into order November 7
column4: which was written to allow the Bajagua project to move forward. The master plan was a binational collaborative effort by EPA and CESPT and addressed San Diego-Tijuana's needs for the next 20 years. The plants are intended to treat approximately 5mgd each
column5: to tertiary levels and provide the reclaimed water to the surrounding areas for agriculture
column6: industry etc. There are several issues that they are facing: no infrastructure to convey the reclaimed water to customers and inadequate groundwater recharge infrastructure.

column1: ==== Telecommunications ====
Tijuana's telephonic system operates under area code 664
column2: but it is not the same area code 664 that is part of the North American Numbering Plan (NANP) because Mexico is not one of the countries represented in the North American Numbering Plan Administration (NANPA) where the country code is 1. So
column3: to dial a phone number from San Diego to Tijuana requires an international access code and Mexico's Country Code
column5: before dialing the area code and the number.  It is similar for anyone calling from Tijuana to the United States.

column1: Telephonic landlines in Tijuana are provided by the company Telnor; other companies include Axtel
column2: Izzi Telecom and Alestra. Popular cell phone carriers in the city-region include Movistar
column3: Telcel
column4: and AT&T Mexico. Many U.S. carriers such as Verizon
column5: AT&T
column6: and T-Mobile offer free roaming in Mexico and it is possible to connect to U.S. based cell phone towers in many northern parts of the city. Cell phones also have historic usage in Tijuana as the first cellular call in Mexico was made in Tijuana in 1989.

column1: === Transportation ===
Tijuana is a major gateway to the interior of Mexico to which it is connected by air and road directly
column2: and by sea via the ports of Ensenada and San Diego. Within Tijuana there are freeways and other roads
column3: and buses
column4: but no passenger rail.

column1: Local public transportation in Tijuana is run by semiprivate companies
column2: and has one of the most complex
column3: or perhaps unorganized networks.

column1: The Tijuana International Airport (General Abelardo L. Rodríguez IA) is the city's main airport
column2: one of the busiest in Mexico
column3: and serves eleven airlines with destinations across Mexico and Shanghai
column4: China. Tijuana Airport is also a second main airport for the San Diego area for passengers heading south into Mexico and Latin America
column5: who may use the airport's Cross Border Xpress terminal located on the U.S. side of the border in Otay Mesa and connected to the rest of the airport on the Mexican side by a pedestrian toll bridge. U.S. and Canadian destinations can be reached via the San Diego International Airport
column6: located about 35 kilometers (22 mi) north of the international border.

column1: Two important Mexican federal highway corridors start in Tijuana
column2: one of them is Fed 1
column3: which runs south through the Baja California Peninsula through Rosarito Beach
column4: Baja Mar
column5: and Ensenada before ending in Cabo San Lucas
column6: Baja California Sur. From Tijuana to Ensenada
column7: most travelers take Fed 1D (scenic road)
column8: a four-lane
column9: limited access toll road that runs by the coast starting at Playas de Tijuana. Fed 2 runs east for 1
column10: 000 kilometers (620 miles) near the international border
column11: as far as Ciudad Juárez

column1: Within the metropolitan area the Corredor Tijuana-Rosarito 2000 freeway connecte Mesa de Otay in the northeast of the city with Rosarito Beach in the southwest.
Just north of the San Ysidro border crossing
column2: Interstate 5 and Interstate 805 head northbound to San Diego and beyond. From the Otay Mesa border crossing
column3: California State Route 905 takes drivers west to connect with California State Route 125 toll road
column4: as well as both I-805 and I-5 .

column1: ==== Intercity buses ====
The city's main bus station is in its eastern borough. A small terminal downtown serves a few Mexican bus lines
column2: and U.S.-based Greyhound Lines and Crucero USA. Another bus station near the border provides frequent service to Ensenada
column3: and other major cities—including Mazatlán
column4: Culiacán
column5: Hermosillo
column6: and Guadalajara. Major bus lines operating in Tijuana include Azul y Blanco de Magallanes (Blue & White) and Transporte Efectivo Express de Tijuana – TEEXTI; modernizing system originally intended to phase out the other lines that partially introduced but ceased and merged with Azul y Blanco.

column1: ==== Local buses ====

column2: Tijuana underwent a major overhaul of its existing system of guayines
column3: or shared fixed-route station wagons
column4: forcing the replacement of the guayines with new models of vans
column5: serving as fixed-route taxis. Major transit hubs include Centro (Downtown Tijuana)
column6: Otay
column7: Soler
column8: and the Cinco y Diez avenues. Taxi lines operating in the city include Free Taxis
column9: those that do not maintain a specific route; Economic Taxis; Diamond Taxis – black or yellow cabs; and regular taxis maintaining a set route. There are as many bus lines and routes as fixed-route taxi ones or calafias
column10: and new routes for buses
column11: taxis or calafias are frequently created
column12: due to high demand of public transportation. Public transportation service is inexpensive
column14: USD $0.75. Fixed-route taxis are somewhat more expensive
column17: taxi and calafia lines and routes are distinguished from one another by their vehicles colors.

column1: ==== Bus rapid transit ====
A bus rapid transit system SITT operates one route from Downtown Tijuana and Garita Puerto Mexico near the San Ysidro Port of Entry
column2: southeasterly along the Tijuana River to Terminal Insurgentes in the southeast of the city. It is part of a planned system of main and feeder lines to replace other buses and minibuses.

column1: ==== Light rail ====
Previously there have been plans for a light rail service
column2: for example in January 2009
column3: the City Council and the Ministry of Communications and Transportation announced such a system along the Tijuana River
column4: however so far nothing has come of these plans.There is
column5: however
column6: a light rail connection via the San Diego Trolley's Blue Line to downtown San Diego and beyond
column7: starting immediately north of the San Ysidro Port of Entry to the U.S. at the San Ysidro Transit Center
column8: where municipal buses also operate.

column1: ==== Ride share ====
Ride share services Uber and DiDi operate throughout Tijuana and surrounding cities.
